sections.title: Support for jaw pain, clenching, and TMJ symptoms
sections.body: We assess why your jaw feels tight, sore, or clicks, then plan care that could include bite guards, muscle relief, and referral when needed.
bullets: Calm assessment of clenching, grinding, or jaw fatigue
Custom bite guards and self-care guidance
Referral pathways if imaging or specialist input is needed

sections.title: Clinician-led and conservative first
items: Assessment includes bite, muscle tenderness, and wear patterns
Jaw care planned around lifestyle, stress, and existing dental work
Night or day guard options reviewed with lab-made or 3D printed occlusal splints
When symptoms suggest joint pathology, we coordinate imaging or specialist referral
Clear safety advice, including when to use emergency dentistry if pain escalates

sections.title: We listen, examine, and plan
sections.body: Your clinician will explore your symptoms—morning jaw ache, headaches, clicking, or limited opening. We check muscles, joints, and tooth wear, then discuss whether self-care, guards, or further imaging are appropriate.
bullets: Medical and dental history, including stress or sleep impacts
Examination of jaw range, clicks, tenderness, and tooth wear
Discuss contributing factors like clenching, grinding, or airway concerns
If needed, link to mouth guard options or restorative adjustments
Explain when specialist TMJ referral or imaging is advised

sections.title: Patients experiencing jaw strain
items: People who clench or grind with morning soreness or headaches
Patients with clicking joints or limited opening
Those noticing tooth wear, chipped edges, or muscle fatigue
Anyone whose jaw symptoms worsen during long treatments
Patients needing guidance before restorative or implant work

sections.title: Stepwise support for jaw comfort
items: Initial consultation and symptom review
Bite and muscle assessment with photos or scans if needed
Discuss self-care, stretching, and habit changes
Plan for a custom guard or restorative adjustments if indicated
Follow-up to review comfort and fit
Escalate to imaging or specialist input if symptoms persist
sections.strapline: Timelines vary; we keep you informed and align with any ongoing care such as implants or orthodontics.

sections.title: Protect your jaw day-to-day
items: Follow exercises and warm compress guidance to ease muscles
Use custom guards as directed; bring them to reviews for adjustments
Maintain regular dental checks to monitor wear and bite
Seek emergency support if you experience jaw locking or sudden swelling
We’ll discuss when referral to TMJ or physiotherapy colleagues is appropriate

faqs.question: Do I always need a night guard?
faqs.answer: Not always. We only recommend a guard when it suits your symptoms and bite. Some cases respond well to self-care, stretching, or adjusting existing dental work.

faqs.question: Can jaw pain be linked to stress or sleep?
faqs.answer: Yes. We explore lifestyle, breathing, and sleep factors. Support may include guards plus advice on habit changes and when to seek medical or physiotherapy input.

faqs.question: Will treatment affect other dental work?
faqs.answer: We plan around your restorations, implants, or orthodontics. Guards and adjustments are tailored to protect existing work while easing symptoms.

faqs.question: When should I seek urgent help?
faqs.answer: If your jaw locks, you can’t fully open, or swelling or pain escalates, contact us or emergency dentistry promptly.

faqs.question: How long until I feel improvement?
faqs.answer: Many patients notice changes after consistent self-care and guard use, but timelines vary. We review progress and adjust the plan if needed.

sections.title: Plan your TMJ care with a calm consult
sections.body: Book a TMJ assessment to discuss symptoms, guards, and when referral makes sense. We’ll coordinate with other care like mouth guards, implants, or orthodontics.
